['Victorian-era innovation: Telegraphy (Telegraph) - The invention and widespread adoption of the electric telegraph during the late 19th century revolutionized communication, with notable milestones occurring around this time period.', 'Transportation advancement: Bessemer Steel Process - In 1856, Sir Henry Bessemer patented his invention for steel production through a process that significantly reduced costs and increased efficiency of the manufacturing method by 1877.', 'Architectural marvels: Eiffel Tower (completed) - The iconic French tower was completed on March 31, 1889, but its initial construction began in August 1877 under the direction of engineer Gustave Eiffel.', 'Industrial progress: Bessemer Converter - An industrial process developed by Sir Henry Bessemer for mass-producing steel, which greatly impacted various industries and infrastructures worldwide by around 1877.', "Technological innovation: Electric Light Bulb (incandescent bulbs) - Thomas Edison's practical incandescent light bulb was patented in November 1879, but significant advancements and commercialization efforts were made by that time.", 'Transport revolution: First Subway System (London Underground) - The London Underground opened to the public on January 10, 1863, although its construction began earlier in the 1850s; however, this milestone represents a significant transportation development around the late 19th century.', 'Medical breakthrough: Anesthesia (general anaesthetics) - While anesthetic techniques were used before 1877, it was not until later that general anesthetics became more widely accepted and utilized in surgical procedures.', 'Industrial advancement: Welding Techniques - The introduction of arc welding by Nikolay Benardos in 1881, but significant research and development in the field were being conducted during this period.', 'Educational reform: Public Education Movement - This movement began earlier with figures like Horace Mann in the mid-19th century; however, various efforts to expand access to public education continued throughout the latter part of the century.', 'Social reforms: Labor Unions and Strikes (Germany) - The late 19th century witnessed a surge in labor union activities and strikes across Europe as workers fought for better working conditions, wages, and rights.', 'Artistic development: Impressionism (movement) - Although the impressionist movement officially began in Paris in April 1874 with its first exhibition, it gained significant popularity by 1877.', 'Sports evolution: Modern Tennis Rules and Court Designs - While tennis itself dates back to the medieval era, modern rules and court designs were developed during this time period.', 'Entertainment innovation: Photography (Color Processes) - Color photography was experimented with by pioneers like James Clerk Maxwell and Louis Ducos du Hauron in the late 19th century.', 'Science breakthroughs: Germ Theory of Disease - While germ theory had been proposed before, it gained more widespread acceptance among scientists and physicians during this time period.', "Cultural influence: Victorian Fashion (Men's Tailcoat) - Men's tailcoats were popular in the 19th century; however, its peak of fashion would be seen around the mid to late 1800s.", 'Industrial growth: Railroads Expansion - The rapid expansion and improvement of railways throughout much of Europe and North America continued during this period.', 'Economic development: Rise of Capitalism (Second Industrial Revolution) - The late 19th century saw the continuation and spread of industrial capitalism, with significant economic growth across various sectors worldwide.', "Engineering marvels: Bridge Construction (Eiffel Tower) - While Eiffel's bridge designs had begun earlier, his most famous creation, the Eiffel Tower, would be completed in 1889, nearing this timeframe.", 'Political reform: Socialist Ideals and Movements - The late 19th century saw significant growth of socialist ideologies and political movements across Europe.', 'Technological advancements: Steam Ship Technology (Ocean liners) - While steamships had been used before, major advancements in ocean liner technology occurred throughout this time period, including the launching of larger ships like the SS Great Eastern by Isambard Kingdom Brunel in 1857.']
